digital-scale.name: Digital scale
digital-scale.description: Precision scale for measuring oils, lye, and additives by weight.
digital-scale.details: A scale is essential for soapmaking. Volume-based measuring is not precise enough for predictable results.
considerations: Ensure maximum weight capacity suits your needs
Recommended precision to 0.1g (1g is acceptable for large batches)
Tare function is required
Must be at least splash resistant, but waterproof preferred

immersion-blender.name: Immersion blender (stick blender)
immersion-blender.description: Handheld immersion blender used to emulsify oils and lye solution and quickly bring mixture to trace.
immersion-blender.details: An immersion blender reduces mixing time from 30 to 60 minutes (if stirring by hand) to 2 to 5 minutes. Use short bursts of 2 to 3 seconds, alternating with stirring to avoid reaching trace unexpectedly quickly.
considerations: Must have a stainless steel shaft (not aluminium, which reacts with lye)
Best to dedicate to soapmaking only to avoid cross-contamination with food
Recommend 200W+ to ensure thick batters don't stop it
safetyNotes: Never use while the fat/lye solution is hot
Keep blade submerged while blender is running to prevent splashing

silicone-mould.name: Silicone mould
silicone-mould.description: Flexible silicone mould for shaping soap.
silicone-mould.details: Silicone allows soap to release easily without sticking and insulates well, which promotes gel phase.
considerations: Choose food-grade silicone rated to 230째C
Some need external support (wooden frame)

wooden-loaf-mould.name: Wooden loaf mould
wooden-loaf-mould.description: Wooden box mould lined with freezer paper or silicone. Provides excellent insulation for gel phase.
wooden-loaf-mould.details: Wooden moulds insulate well, which promotes an gel phase throughout the loaf.
considerations: Heavier and less flexible than silicone
Requires lining (freezer paper, silicone); unlined wood will become unusable as it becomes saturated with moisture and soap.

safety-goggles.name: Safety goggles
safety-goggles.description: Chemical splash goggles that seal around the eyes to protect against lye splashes.
safety-goggles.details:
Any glasses with open sides do not protect against vapours or random splashes that can cause serious eye injury.

Choose goggles rated for chemical splash protection, not just impact protection, with indirect ventilation to prevent fogging while keeping liquids out.
considerations: Must seal completely around eyes
Must be chemical splash rated (ANSI Z87.1 or equivalent)
Anti-fog coating or indirect ventilation is helpful
Should fit over prescription glasses if needed
safetyNotes: Wear whenever handling lye or raw soap

references.section: ANSI/ISEA Z87.1 Eye and Face Protection
references.note: American standard for occupational eye and face protection

rubber-gloves.name: Rubber gloves
rubber-gloves.description: Chemical-resistant gloves to protect hands from lye and raw soap batter.
rubber-gloves.details: Nitrile or neoprene gloves provide good protection against lye. Latex may degrade faster with repeated exposure, but works if disposable latex gloves are all you have available.
considerations: Choose gloves with a minimum 8 mil thickness for durability if using reusable gloves
Opt for wrist-length gloves as a minimum; choose elbow-length gloves when handling large batches of chemicals
safetyNotes: Wear whenever handling lye or raw soap
Check for holes before each use and replace if torn or punctured
Wash gloves before removing to prevent caustic drips

references.note: Chemical resistance guidance for protective equipment

thermometer.name: Thermometer
thermometer.description: Device for monitoring fat and lye solution temperatures.
thermometer.details: Ideally, start the mixed melted fat and lye solution at 38 - 54째C to avoid false trace.
considerations: Range: at least 0-120째C
Probe type more accurate than infrared, which measure surface temperature only
Instant-read digital models most convenient
Best practice to dedicate one to soapmaking to avoid cross-contamination concerns

soap-cutter.name: Soap cutter
soap-cutter.description: Tool for cutting loaf soap into uniform bars
soap-cutter.details: You can use a knife, a wire stretched across a frame, or specialized multi-bar cutters; aim to cut soap while it's firm but not very hard.
considerations: Wire cutters provide clean cuts with minimal drag
A knife provides more control but may drag through soft soap
Multi-bar cutters helf achieve consistent thickness
A mitre box helps achieve straight cuts

mixing-containers.name: Mixing containers
mixing-containers.description: Heat-resistant containers for mixing lye solution and combining with oils. Must be lye-safe materials.
mixing-containers.details:
For lye, use heat-resistant plastic (PP #5, HDPE #2), stainless steel, or tempered/borosilicate glass.

For soap batter, use stainless steel or heavy-duty plastic pitchers.
considerations: Heat-resistant to at least 93째C
Wide opening for stirring
Pour spout helpful for moulding
safetyNotes: NEVER use aluminum, which is violently reactive with lye
Check recycling code on plastic (PP #5 or HDPE #2 only)
Inspect for cracks before each use
Dedicate to soapmaking to avoid cross-contamination with food

curing-rack.name: Curing rack
curing-rack.description: Open-air rack for curing soap bars. Allows air circulation on all sides for even water evaporation.
curing-rack.details: Soap needs 4 to 6 weeks of curing time after unmoulding (and, if using a loaf mould, slicing) for water to evaporate and saponification to complete.
considerations: Use an open design for air circulation on all sides
Ensure it's sturdy enough to hold multiple batches
Place in cool, dry area with good airflow
Avoid direct sunlight
